segment.source: Uniquely identifies object elements for access to the instantiated object from code-behind or general code.
segment.target: Uniquely identifies object elements for access to the instantiated object from code-behind or general code.

segment.source: xName attribute
segment.target: xName attribute

segment.source: x:Name attribute
segment.target: x:Name attribute

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Uniquely identifies object elements for access to the instantiated object from code-behind or general code.
segment.target: Uniquely identifies object elements for access to the instantiated object from code-behind or general code.

segment.source: Once applied to a backing programming model, x:Name can be considered equivalent to the variable holding an object reference, as returned by a constructor.
segment.target: Once applied to a backing programming model, x:Name can be considered equivalent to the variable holding an object reference, as returned by a constructor.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: XAML values
segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: XAMLNameValue
segment.target: XAMLNameValue

segment.source: A string that conforms to the restrictions of the XamlName grammar.
segment.target: A string that conforms to the restrictions of the XamlName grammar.

segment.source: XamlName grammar
segment.target: XamlName grammar

segment.source: The following is the normative grammar for a string that is used as a key in this XAML implementation:
segment.target: The following is the normative grammar for a string that is used as a key in this XAML implementation:

segment.source: Characters are restricted to the lower ASCII range, and more specifically to Roman alphabet uppercase and lowercase letters, digits, and the underscore (\_) character.
segment.target: Characters are restricted to the lower ASCII range, and more specifically to Roman alphabet uppercase and lowercase letters, digits, and the underscore (\_) character.

segment.source: The Unicode character range is not supported.
segment.target: The Unicode character range is not supported.

segment.source: A name cannot begin with a digit.
segment.target: A name cannot begin with a digit.

segment.source: Some tool implementations prepend an underscore (\_) to a string if the user supplies a digit as the initial character, or the tool autogenerates x:Name values based on other values that contain digits.
segment.target: Some tool implementations prepend an underscore (\_) to a string if the user supplies a digit as the initial character, or the tool autogenerates x:Name values based on other values that contain digits.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: The specified x:Name becomes the name of a field that is created in the underlying code when XAML is processed, and that field holds a reference to the object.
segment.target: The specified x:Name becomes the name of a field that is created in the underlying code when XAML is processed, and that field holds a reference to the object.

segment.source: The process of creating this field is performed by the MSBuild target steps, which also are responsible for joining the partial classes for a XAML file and its code-behind.
segment.target: The process of creating this field is performed by the MSBuild target steps, which also are responsible for joining the partial classes for a XAML file and its code-behind.

segment.source: This behavior is not necessarily XAML-language specified; it is the particular implementation that Universal Windows Platform (UWP) programming for XAML applies to use x:Name in its programming and application models.
segment.target: This behavior is not necessarily XAML-language specified; it is the particular implementation that Universal Windows Platform (UWP) programming for XAML applies to use x:Name in its programming and application models.

segment.source: Each defined x:Name must be unique within a XAML namescope.
segment.target: Each defined x:Name must be unique within a XAML namescope.

segment.source: Generally, a XAML namescope is defined at the root element level of a loaded page and contains all elements under that element in a single XAML page.
segment.target: Generally, a XAML namescope is defined at the root element level of a loaded page and contains all elements under that element in a single XAML page.

segment.source: Additional XAML namescopes are defined by any control template or data template that is defined on that page.
segment.target: Additional XAML namescopes are defined by any control template or data template that is defined on that page.

segment.source: At run time, another XAML namescope is created for the root of the object tree that is created from an applied control template, and also by object trees created from a call to XamlReader.Load.
segment.target: At run time, another XAML namescope is created for the root of the object tree that is created from an applied control template, and also by object trees created from a call to XamlReader.Load.

segment.source: For more info, see XAML namescopes.
segment.target: For more info, see XAML namescopes.

segment.source: Design tools often autogenerate x:Name values for elements when they are introduced to the design surface.
segment.target: Design tools often autogenerate x:Name values for elements when they are introduced to the design surface.

segment.source: The autogeneration scheme varies depending on which designer you are using, but a typical scheme is to generate a string that starts with the class name that backs the element, followed by an advancing integer.
segment.target: The autogeneration scheme varies depending on which designer you are using, but a typical scheme is to generate a string that starts with the class name that backs the element, followed by an advancing integer.

segment.source: For example, if you introduce the first Button element to the designer, you might see that in the XAML this element has the x:Name attribute value of "Button1".
segment.target: For example, if you introduce the first Button element to the designer, you might see that in the XAML this element has the x:Name attribute value of "Button1".

segment.source: x:Name cannot be set in XAML property element syntax, or in code using SetValue.
segment.target: x:Name cannot be set in XAML property element syntax, or in code using SetValue.

segment.source: x:Name can only be set using XAML attribute syntax on elements.
segment.target: x:Name can only be set using XAML attribute syntax on elements.

segment.source: Note Specifically for C++/CX apps, a backing field for an x:Name reference is not created for the root element of a XAML file or page.
segment.target: Note Specifically for C++/CX apps, a backing field for an x:Name reference is not created for the root element of a XAML file or page.

segment.source: If you need to reference the root object from C++ code-behind, use other APIs or tree traversal.
segment.target: If you need to reference the root object from C++ code-behind, use other APIs or tree traversal.

segment.source: For example you can call FindName for a known named child element and then call Parent.
segment.target: For example you can call FindName for a known named child element and then call Parent.

segment.source: x:Name and other Name properties
segment.target: x:Name and other Name properties

segment.source: Some types used in UWP XAML also have a property named Name.
segment.target: Some types used in UWP XAML also have a property named Name.

segment.source: For example, FrameworkElement.Name and TextElement.Name.
segment.target: For example, FrameworkElement.Name and TextElement.Name.

segment.source: If Name is available as a settable property on an element, Name and x:Name can be used interchangeably in XAML, but an error results if both attributes are specified on the same element.
segment.target: If Name is available as a settable property on an element, Name and x:Name can be used interchangeably in XAML, but an error results if both attributes are specified on the same element.

segment.source: There are also cases where there's a Name property but it's read-only (like VisualState.Name).
segment.target: There are also cases where there's a Name property but it's read-only (like VisualState.Name).

segment.source: If that's the case you always use x:Name to name that element in the XAML and the read-only Name exists for some less-common code scenario.
segment.target: If that's the case you always use x:Name to name that element in the XAML and the read-only Name exists for some less-common code scenario.

segment.source: Note FrameworkElement.Name generally should not be used as a way to change values originally set by x:Name, although there are some scenarios that are exceptions to that general rule.
segment.target: Note FrameworkElement.Name generally should not be used as a way to change values originally set by x:Name, although there are some scenarios that are exceptions to that general rule.

segment.source: In typical scenarios, the creation and definition of XAML namescopes is a XAML processor operation.
segment.target: In typical scenarios, the creation and definition of XAML namescopes is a XAML processor operation.

segment.source: Modifying FrameworkElement.Name at run time can result in an inconsistent XAML namescope / private field naming alignment, which is hard to keep track of in your code-behind.
segment.target: Modifying FrameworkElement.Name at run time can result in an inconsistent XAML namescope / private field naming alignment, which is hard to keep track of in your code-behind.

segment.source: x:Name and x:Key
segment.target: x:Name and x:Key

segment.source: x:Name can be applied as an attribute to elements within a ResourceDictionary to act as a substitute for the x:Key attribute.
segment.target: x:Name can be applied as an attribute to elements within a ResourceDictionary to act as a substitute for the x:Key attribute.

segment.source: (Normally it's a rule that all elements in a ResourceDictionary must have an x:Key attribute.) This is common for Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: (Normally it's a rule that all elements in a ResourceDictionary must have an x:Key attribute.) This is common for Storyboarded animations.

segment.source: For more info, see section of ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
segment.target: For more info, see section of ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
